title: About ME
text: Hello my name is Emilie Chi! I am currently a sophomore at the University of Pennsylvania, and am majoring in Communications (Concentration: Data and Network Science) and minoring in Consumer Psychology. This blog will capture my exploration and experimentation of language Models in my ‘Stories from data: Programming for Data Journalism’ UPENN Clas

title: Is extroversion related to race
text:
The dataset consists of 19,719 users of varied backgrounds who have responded to 49 personality questions that pertain to the Big 5 personality test. It also asks for demographic information including race, age, gender, country of orgin, etc, in which I only be investigating the race aspect of the dataset. Race was recorded numerically, and then mapped into descriptive labels.
The 49 questions asked were as followed:

The E2, E3, E4 are symbols that represent the 49 indivual questions of the Big 5 personality test in which the users would respond to on a 1-5 scale (1 being a strong no and a 5 indicating a strong yes).



pd.DataFrame([item.split('\t') for item in questions.splitlines() if item>''])

import pandas as pd
import re

big5_df = pd.read_csv('data/openpsych_data.csv', sep='\t')

title: Is extroversion related to race
section: Defining extroversion in this big data set:
text:
Defining extroversion in this big data set:
To actually start finding the answer to the question, I have to find the extroversion score for each user. To find extroversion from the entire test, I summed the responses (numerical values 1-being strong no, 2-being strong yes) of these five questions in the 49 question set that described extroverted qualities in the best capacity: - E1: “I am the life of the party” - E3: “I feel comfortable around peoplea - E5:”I start conversations” - E7: “I talk to a lot of different people at parties” - E9: “I don’t mind being the center of attention”

Each numerical value for the questions were added to make a total that defined each user’s Extroversion Value:

big5_df["E_value"] = big5_df[["E1", "E3", "E5", "E7", "E9" ]].sum(axis=1)



This would create a seperate column in the compiled chart that gave each user an Extroversion score or E_value


It looked something like this:

5 rows × 59 columns





Now I had to find the important stuff which was association. This was found by grouping each user by race, and then averaging the Extroversion scores (E_value) to calculate the total average extroversion score for each race:

group = big5_df.groupby("race_cat") 


race_avg = group["E_value"].mean()

title: Is extroversion related to race
text:
Results Raw Data:
The number accompanying each race is the average extroversion score (the higher the number, the higher the extroversion level)

Since I was born in 2006, majority of the years since I was alive on the day of my birthday in Philadelphia it did not rain. (13 years it did not and 7 years it did).

D) What day of the week was it?

dow_name

Sunday       3
Tuesday      3

Thursday     3
Friday       2
Name: count, dtype: int64



Since I was born in 2006, the largest amount of my birthdays have fallen on a Monday.

title: Dataset of the Week #1: The Weather in Philadelphia
text:
Conclusion
The weather in Philadelphia on the days of my birthday for the past twenty years was something I was curious about, especially to see if there was a pattern that I can relate back to myself. I found that majority of my birthdays fell on a Monday, it did snow nor rain for most of the years, and the avgerage temperature was 32 degrees on my birthdays put together. So overall, most of my birthdays throughout the years here in Philadelphia were not extremely cold, but still on the chillier side. I find that interesting, because I spent my recent birthday in 2026 freezing, because of how cold it was from the piled up snow from the previous snow storm and high winds. I thought this was the norm weather here in Philadelphia on Jan 30, but referencing past years’ data it shows otherwise. This was an interesting finding.
